the places, the institutions where the memory is kept.

there is no way that such an attack and such a destruction can be fruitful because if you have in your mind several verses of your favorite poet and if all the books of that poet

What you really love and cherish.

the new virtual reality.

You know what me and my wife did?
How I sing a lullaby to my wife.
Because lullaby, lullaby is to go to sleep.
I'm just saying it from the tape so I can understand it when I come to... We have lots of useless time because there is no electricity and you have to be very careful where to put the oil.

in our meal or spend it on the light.

So we were talking.
What we did?

We sing to each other, different kind of a tune.
Then we repeat it again.
Then we sing.
summarize and repeating all the books that we have read.
Then we reread the library, the home library that we have.
And then we do it again and again and again.
In order to keep ourselves busy, to provoke a fine feeling, a good vibration, and we stop

doing this ritual of falling asleep because if I fall asleep first if I fall asleep I start snoring I developed a habit to sleep my wife is going to sleep first so I can easily fall asleep and snore but she sleeps very deeply
And I start this ritual of recollecting the memory, what we read, what we've gone through, where have we been, all these things endlessly.
Because my wife at a certain point says, oh please shut up, you are repeating yourself.
You know, it practically means I got out of the tunes.
Needless to tell you that I recollect all the Beatles tunes, all the Rolling Stones tunes.
I mean, I have a specials like Moody Blues, hundreds of thousands of the tunes that I sing to my wife as a lullaby.
So it was interesting to her to get you to sleep.
All after all, I had to go all over again.
And she said, oh, forget it.
You are repeating yourself.
Amazing.
You know, when you do not add the fresh information, the new books that you like to read, you do, you may not have to do what you may not have to do.
You have to recollect it.
to emphasize.
You know, but also to reinforce it in a way.
We are talking about things that keeps us alive.
Alive in a sense that we are alive.
And repetition is one way to do it, of course, is what you're saying, I guess.
Yes.
Definitely.
Now,
I understand that the night that the library burned, there was a chain of people trying to rescue books, and there was a young woman who was shot to death, is that not?

Aida Buturevich, a colleague of mine, and a good friend of mine, died
while she was returning for home, I think two or three days before the burn-out of my day.
That really didn't happen.
That really didn't happen.

The tragic story of Aida Baturi's parents is the following.
His father was so upset.

I'll be there.

Amazing personality.

So I will use that opportunity to teach them how to handle the groups.

or to the problem of how to get life into the university community.

Yeah.

Something like that.
So, whatever.
But for a young man,
Tell me what you felt when you started out in life as a professional person.
Did you think that at the age of 40 that this is what you're doing today?
No.
First of all, I have an enormous sense of guilt with my wife because I lied to her.
In fact, I lied to myself that this madness will be over in the 50 days.
50 days, yeah.
That is what I've done to my life.
Believe me, Marina, this will be ended in the 50 days.
And this is about when, when you're saying this?
I'd say April 1992.
Okay.
So I was wrong because before the war I was...
I was not a public person.
I didn't hold it just in the ministry.
I was just... Your life was books.
My life was books and I was some kind of a homegrown dinosaur.
My wife and the library... What is all about?
I spent endless hours in the library writing on my PhD thesis.
Where did you write?
On my PhD thesis.
And definitely...
take care of my life.
And the home.
I didn't read daily newspaper.
I wasn't able to politics, not part of the home or any party, you know.
You're a librarian.
I'm just a librarian.
And then the things happened the way they happened.
In fact, they dropped me.
They what?
They dropped me.
Well, they drafted you for the army.
Not for the area, thanks God for the Ministry of Defence.
But my job was also to take care of parts of the collections, military collections of documents and some portions of the library that could be in the city.
And after they just simply drafted me to the Ministry of Education to do what I was going to do.
So I joined the Ministry of Education in January 1994 when Hari Sarajis was elected to be a Prime Minister.
So we have a wonderful time and lots of time to discuss the key issue, what we're going to do.

in a more than desperate situation when your country is under total bankruptcy, when you have officially authority to take care, to maintain all the things which is under your auspicious, but you do not have the means to do this and to envisage some kind of a future of possible solutions.
So, it was quite an interesting episode of what I like.
More or less I'm
I learned a lot, that's the first thing.
And the second thing, we achieved a lot.
We achieved a lot because we were crazy enough to think strategically in the times of the war, which is not a good thing.
War is something that totally shakes all the structures.
What did you do your PhD on?
My PhD is very specific.
Basically, it's an information science, a simple field called bibliometrics.
I invented and I produced
Science citation index for the field of archaeology of Bosnia.
Just to get the exact numbers and figures and patterns, charts, maps, diagrams, what is the actual information flow in historical scientific science?

On the basis of this statistical result, I try to develop some kind of a political system, an expert system for the museum, meaning how to connect, how to link various information sources like library, like collections, like documentation, like

cadastres like maps into a system that will provide you sufficient information as a background reading before you go to the specific site to dig and what are your obligations after you did your digging as an archaeologist so you were pure scholar absolutely but unfortunately
I do not have the time and the need to continue my research in that area but in the meantime I discovered in my library and museum some manuscripts that are unknown to the public and I tried to
making some kind of a hobby.
I made some kind of a lucky lady.
Lucky lady.
And it's all prior to the catastrophe in 1992.
Maybe five days before all started in Sarajevo, I discovered a manuscript that was considered to be lost.
And that is an amazing story.
It's a Bosnian-Serbian author from the city of Moscow.
Mostar in Herzegovina.
So I retyped the whole manuscript in my computer and my wife always made complaints stating to whom are you typing this manuscript?
It's a Serbian author from the city of Mostar who is over, who is on the siege of the Croatian forces.
I said, maybe this war will be ended soon and it will be a hit.
Unknown drama, three acts, totally unknown manuscripts.
Accidentally I found it because it was folded in some other envelope.
That's a great story.
And how large is it, physically?
Physically, it's a normal free-act drama, 72 pages of a manuscript, practically less than 60 pages of a typescript.
What is the significance of it, would you say, historically?
Okay, a new volume to the complete volume of one of the most productive and most beautiful authors, Bosnian-Serbian authors.
Authors?
Yeah, writers.
This is for the tape, so when I can... Go ahead, I'm sorry.
So I added another volume to his complete volume.
And what's his name once more?
Svetozar Chorovic.
So you didn't tell me that.
How would I spell that?
S-V-E-T.
And I'll be able to find this too.
So this was a very significant find then, wasn't it?
Yes, but that happened.
week before it all started, but on the very same day.
This was a week before?
Yes, it was 1st of April, for example, and all started on 6th, April 6th, with those riots and demonstrations in front of the House of the Parliament and the first sniper shooting in the city.
But on the very day, this is also the tragic story, on the very day when all had happened, I was in the museum and discovered another set of the manuscripts.
These are the manuscripts of the folk songs from the First World War.
Really?
So like I was predicting that there would be another war.
Jeez, I just hit him.
That car just hit back.
So were these items saved or were they lost in the war?
No, no, I just took them to my place, did the retyping.
So they were saved?
Yeah, they were saved.
Because you took them home to retype them?
Yes, I just retyped them and then returned them to the museum.
But you know, if I search for these items for ten years, there is no way that I can find them.
But the silly thing that I had to evacuate all my collections, you know.
I had to pick all this stuff and, you know.

Yes.
